title: Paul Routledge: It’s Yeti another clue Johnson isn’t one of us
text:

Eton College doesn’t blow its own trumpet very much.

The elite public school that produced 20 British prime ministers is discreet about the behaviour of the rich kids behind its high walls.

That’s the way the parents who pay £42,501 a year fees (what’s that last quid for?) like it.

But an old Etonian has spilled the beans about one of his famous fellow pupils.

Let me tell you what he thinks about his contemporary Alexander de Pfeffel Johnson, who trades under the name of Boris.

James Wood, a Durham-born writer who went to the school as a middle-class scholarship boy, says: “Johnson looked very much at 15 as he does at 55, and was a familiar sight as he charged and flapped around the college lanes.

“The big-foot stoop (he was known as ‘the Yeti’), the bumbling confidence, the skimmed-milk pallor, the berserk hair, the alarming air of imminent self-harm, which gave the impression that he had been freshly released from some ­protective institution: all was already in place.”

A brilliant pen-portrait. Immediately recognisable as the spoilt brat who never grew up, but achieved his boyish ­ambition to be the 20th Old Etonian in No10.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Wood, writing in a recent London Review of Books, identifies the Eton mantra of “effortless superiority” behind a Brexit madness casually instituted, secretly engineered and noisily bolstered by a cabal of old Etonians born between 1963 and 1975, the year we joined the Common Market.

Phew! So we are leaving Europe because a gang of toffs who never wanted for anything – and never will – decided that should be the nation’s future.

“Cameron, Johnson and Rees-Mogg belong to the same world,” says Wood.

“A world of extreme wealth where there has never been any decline for them.”

It’s a pity we had to wait until now, when it’s too late, for this candid ­exposure of life at the top to emerge.

If the car workers of Sunderland and Swindon had known what was planned for them, they might have voted ­differently in the referendum.

The Yeti – the Abominable No-Man – stalking Westminster could have been stopped in his big-foot tracks.
